item.title: 真理几何？
item.description: 丘成桐分享的数学哲学：真理隐藏在最对称简洁的结构中，美即是真。通过六维卷缩、红楼架构、工具与视野、无畏提问、抗压教育和超越功利等六大心法，阐述数学家的思维方式与教育理念。

item.title: Straussian Memes Visual Deck
item.description: 这是一份基于施特劳斯哲学概念构建的视觉卡片，探讨了现代信息传播中的双层结构。它揭示了大众流行叙事背后的商业与心理机制，分析了通过‘身份认同’和‘社会成本’构建的上下防御屏障，并提供了在折叠的真理中建立清醒免疫系统的洞察。

item.title: 诺姆·乔姆斯基与米歇尔·福柯的人性辩论全记录
item.description: 这场1971年的经典辩论汇聚了乔姆斯基与福柯两位思想巨擘，围绕“人性”的本质展开激烈交锋。文章探讨了先天认知结构与权力知识网络的根本对立，分析了创造力、正义与文明概念在两种世界观下的截然不同的解读。通过对比语言学上的普遍语法与哲学中的历史系谱学，展示了人类理解自身与社会的两种核心路径。

item.title: 存在主义哲学导论
item.description: 本文是一份关于存在主义哲学的交互式导论，深入探讨了“存在先于本质”的核心思想以及自由、焦虑与荒诞等关键概念。文章详细介绍了萨特、加缪和海德格尔等代表人物及其生平，分析了《存在与虚无》、《局外人》和《存在与时间》等重要著作，为理解这一关注人类生存状态的哲学流派提供了全面的视觉化指南。

item.description:

What to Do

March 2025

What should one do? That may seem a strange question, but it’s not meaningless or unanswerable. It’s the sort of question kids ask before they learn not to ask big questions. I only came across it myself in the process of investigating something else. But once I did, I thought I should at least try to answer it.

The Best Essay

March 2024

Despite its title this isn’t meant to be the best essay. My goal here is to figure out what the best essay would be like.

It would be well-written, but you can write well about any topic. What made it special would be what it was about.

item.title: What You (Want to)* Want
item.description:
→ 中文版本

https://www.paulgraham.com/want.html

What You (Want to)* Want

November 2022

Since I was about 9 I’ve been puzzled by the apparent contradiction between being made of matter that behaves in a predictable way, and the feeling that I could choose to do whatever I wanted. At the time I had a self-interested motive for exploring the question. At that age (like most succeeding ages) I was always in trouble with the authorities, and it seemed to me that there might possibly be some way to get out of trouble by arguing that I wasn’t responsible for my actions. I gradually lost hope of that, but the puzzle remained: How do you reconcile being a machine made of matter with the feeling that you’re free to choose what you do? [1]

item.title: Alien Truth
item.description:
→ 中文版本

https://www.paulgraham.com/alien.html

Alien Truth

October 2022

If there were intelligent beings elsewhere in the universe, they’d share certain truths in common with us. The truths of mathematics would be the same, because they’re true by definition. Ditto for the truths of physics; the mass of a carbon atom would be the same on their planet. But I think we’d share other truths with aliens besides the truths of math and physics, and that it would be worthwhile to think about what these might be.

item.title: The Lesson to Unlearn
item.description:
→ 中文版本

https://www.paulgraham.com/lesson.html

The Lesson to Unlearn

December 2019

The most damaging thing you learned in school wasn’t something you learned in any specific class. It was learning to get good grades.

When I was in college, a particularly earnest philosophy grad student once told me that he never cared what grade he got in a class, only what he learned in it. This stuck in my mind because it was the only time I ever heard anyone say such a thing.

item.title: Persuade xor Discover
item.description:

https://www.paulgraham.com/discover.html

Persuade xor Discover

September 2009

When meeting people you don’t know very well, the convention is to seem extra friendly. You smile and say “pleased to meet you,” whether you are or not. There’s nothing dishonest about this. Everyone knows that these little social lies aren’t meant to be taken literally, just as everyone knows that “Can you pass the salt?” is only grammatically a question.

Keep Your Identity Small

February 2009

I finally realized today why politics and religion yield such uniquely useless discussions.

As a rule, any mention of religion on an online forum degenerates into a religious argument. Why? Why does this happen with religion and not with Javascript or baking or other topics people talk about on forums?

item.title: How to Disagree
item.description:
→ Chinese Version

https://www.paulgraham.com/disagree.html

How to Disagree

March 2008

The web is turning writing into a conversation. Twenty years ago, writers wrote and readers read. The web lets readers respond, and increasingly they do—in comment threads, on forums, and in their own blog posts.

Many who respond to something disagree with it. That’s to be expected. Agreeing tends to motivate people less than disagreeing. And when you agree there’s less to say. You could expand on something the author said, but he has probably already explored the most interesting implications. When you disagree you’re entering territory he may not have explored.

item.title: How to Do Philosophy
item.description:
→ 中文版本

https://www.paulgraham.com/philosophy.html

How to Do Philosophy

September 2007

In high school I decided I was going to study philosophy in college. I had several motives, some more honorable than others. One of the less honorable was to shock people. College was regarded as job training where I grew up, so studying philosophy seemed an impressively impractical thing to do. Sort of like slashing holes in your clothes or putting a safety pin through your ear, which were other forms of impressive impracticality then just coming into fashion.

item.description:

Is It Worth Being Wise?

February 2007

A few days ago I finally figured out something I’ve wondered about for 25 years: the relationship between wisdom and intelligence. Anyone can see they’re not the same by the number of people who are smart, but not very wise. And yet intelligence and wisdom do seem related. How?

item.title: Copy What You Like
item.description:
→ 中文版本

https://www.paulgraham.com/copy.html

Copy What You Like

July 2006

When I was in high school I spent a lot of time imitating bad writers. What we studied in English classes was mostly fiction, so I assumed that was the highest form of writing. Mistake number one.

The stories that seemed to be most admired were ones in which people suffered in complicated ways. Anything funny or gripping was ipso facto suspect, unless it was old enough to be hard to understand, like Shakespeare or Chaucer. Mistake number two.

item.description:

See Randomness

April 2006, rev August 2009

Plato quotes Socrates as saying “the unexamined life is not worth living.” Part of what he meant was that the proper role of humans is to think, just as the proper role of anteaters is to poke their noses into anthills.
